title: The Calendar Origin
description: Learn why the Ethiopian calendar is 7-8 years behind and understand the unique 13-month system.

parts.title: Why Ethiopia is 7-8 Years Behind: The Annunciation Calculation

data.text: The Ethiopian calendar is 7-8 years behind the Gregorian calendar due to differences in calculating the date of the Annunciation of Jesus Christ's birth.

While both calendars are solar systems with approximately 365-366 days annually, they use different theological frameworks to establish their starting points. The Gregorian calendar calculates years from the Annunciation using one method, while the Ethiopian calendar uses alternate calculations for this same event.
Ethiopia celebrated its millennium (year 2000) on September 12, 2007, in Gregorian terms, while the year 2001 began on September 11, 2008.

points: Difference stems from alternate calculations of the Annunciation
Both systems are solar calendars with similar day counts
The gap is consistent and predictable

parts.title: The 13-Month System: Understanding Ethiopian Calendar Months

data.text: The Ethiopian calendar has a distinctive structure with 12 months of exactly 30 days each, plus a 13th month called Pagumē that contains 5 days in a common year and 6 days in a leap year.

parts.title: Pagumē: The 13th Month and Leap Year System

data.text: Pagumē is the 13th month of the Ethiopian calendar, containing 5 days in a normal year and 6 days in a leap year. The leap year occurs every 4 years without exception and is traditionally called the 'Luke-year' in the 4-year Evangelist cycle.

The Ethiopian calendar adds a leap day to Pagumē every 4 years to maintain solar alignment, similar to how the Gregorian calendar adds a day to February. However, the Ethiopian system uses a simple 4-year rule with no exceptions, unlike the more complex Gregorian formula.

points: Leap day added to Pagumē, not to regular months
Connected to religious tradition through Evangelist naming
